Technically, that wasn't a deep field image. The deep field images are classified by looking at parts of the sky we cant see anything in. We knew there was plenty in JWST image. A true deep field image with James Webb has yet to be conducted.

JWST can see the past light from earth also.
------
If we stand in front of a mirror, light gets reflected back and forth forever.
-----
Similarly, past light from earth also is getting reflected back and forth between earth, atmosphere, planets etc.
--------
For example, they can see the life of Prophet Muhammad sal, Prophet Jesus etc from past light.
------
NASA scientists have seen the life of Prophets from past light and they are keeping it as a top secret.

comment_text:
Does anyone else think Newtonian 1D-4D "necessary" universe is a dead model?

We know all about how important 0, and it's geometric counterpart 0D, are in 2022.

Quantum physics needs a better set of fundamentals than Newton can offer.

Leibniz went into great detail about 0D (point) in his Monadology.

Leibniz knew 0D is necessary and 1D-9D is contingent.

We have a workable ToE right now.
Update Hamilton's 4D quaternion algebra from 1D-4D Newtonian nonsense to Leibniz's 0D-3D.

0D-3D matches quantum physics:

0D (point) is Quark
1D Line is Lepton
2D Plane is Guage Boson
3D Volume is Higgs Boson

0D-3D are our first four dimensions.

1D, 2D, 3D = spatial
(line, width, height)

4D, 5D, 6D = temporal (length, breadth, depth)

7D, 8D, 9D = spectral
(continuous, emission, absorption)

Symmetry/entanglement: 

1D, 4D, 7D line, length, continuous 

2D, 5D, 8D width, breadth, emission 

3D, 6D, 9D height, depth, absorption

I still have one problem with these telescopes. long exposure photography. rivers and creeks don't always have a fast current, but the images still look weird in long exposure, like cars on the street at night. Long exposures of stars generally turn into streaks or blobs if the exposure is too slow. Too fast and it won't get enough light to produce an image. If you want to do long exposure photography of stars from Earth you need the camera to move with the stars to prevent the streaks, and if the camera wobbles even a little the entire thing can come out blurry. I know, the mountains in the back move slower than things that are close, but still. Everything is in space moving around really fast, and the exposure time of the first JWST images took around 19 hours... I'm guessing they probably used the typical astrophotography method of image stacking, and it was probably more like "equivalent to 19 hours" and they just took like 3000 images with 32s exposures and stacked them, while everything moves around really fast, and also in space where things are a bit different than on Earth. I may have come up with the solution to my own issue. It's still mind boggling though. I guess 19 hours doesn't make much difference to light that's 13.5 billion years old. Kind of weird that we can even see that light still. It's probably the closest thing we'll have to time travel; being able to see the light from objects that aren't there anymore. If the Milky Way is swirling and the Earth is just a rock zooming around space then I wonder if we could look back at where Earth used to be 13 million years ago to see what it was like back then. Hell, maybe you can even see last year. Maybe skip last year and go back before covid. How far has Earth travelled in the last 13 million years? It would be neat to have a super powerful telescope at the center of the galaxy right now, taking pictures of us.
